G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: G.L. c. 186, § 14 provides, in relevant part, that a landlord “shall not directly or indirectly interfere with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant.”

Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.raw_text: Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.proposition: Plaintiff’s tenancy is governed by Massachusetts landlord‑tenant law, including but not limited to G.L. c. 186 and G.L. c. 239, and by the implied warranty of habitability and statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.support_reasoning: The opinion (including this concurrence/dissent) squarely treats these as standard Massachusetts landlord‑tenant relationships governed by the summary process statute, G.L. c. 239, and discusses the statutory tenant defenses under § 8A and related sanitary‑code enforcement provisions in c. 111. The justice explicitly agrees that the common‑law no‑repair rule must be reconsidered and that the landlord’s statutory duties and the tenant’s rent obligation should be made mutually interdependent, which is the functional basis of the implied warranty of habitability and covenant of quiet enjoyment as later articulated in Massachusetts law. However, because this is a separate opinion and emphasizes a statutory‑standards‑based implied obligation rather than the broader “implied warranty of habitability” label, it supports the proposition more by affirming that Massachusetts landlord‑tenant law (c. 186, c. 239, sanitary code, and quiet enjoyment concepts) governs such tenancies than by cleanly stating the full proposition in those exact terms.
Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 M.relevant_excerpt: “These *204 are two actions of summary process under G. L. c. 239 against tenants who admittedly had failed to pay their rent… The tenants… claim the protection of… [G. L. c. 239, § 8A]… I agree with the majority of the court that, at least as to dwelling units, the time has come to reconsider the rule… that ‘[t]here is no implied agreement… that the demised premises are or will continue to be fit for occupancy or safe and in good repair…’… As the first step… I would… hold… that… minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards.”

G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7 3.proposition: This action is brought in the Housing Court Department, City of Boston Division, pursuant to G.L. c. 185C, § 3, which grants the Housing Court jurisdiction over actions involving “the health, safety or welfare of any occupant of residential housing” and arising out of the landlord‑tenant relationship.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court because the Premises are located in Roxbury, within the territorial jurisdiction of the Boston Housing Court.

G.L. c. 239.proposition: Plaintiff’s tenancy is governed by Massachusetts landlord‑tenant law, including but not limited to G.L. c. 186 and G.L. c. 239, and by the implied warranty of habitability and statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment.

105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq..proposition: The presence of repeated water infiltration, dampness, and excess moisture in a basement dwelling unit is a condition that endangers or materially impairs the health, safety, or well‑being of occupants and constitutes a violation of the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code.

105 C.M.R. 410.200.proposition: See 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq.; particularly 105 C.M.R. 410.200 (requiring moisture‑resistant, weathertight building elements) and 105 C.M.R. 410.750 (conditions deemed to endanger or materially impair health or safety).

105 C.M.R. 410.750.proposition: See 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq.; particularly 105 C.M.R. 410.200 (requiring moisture‑resistant, weathertight building elements) and 105 C.M.R. 410.750 (conditions deemed to endanger or materially impair health or safety).

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 284 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, the covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in every residential lease or tenancy and protects tenants against serious interferences with their tenancy caused by the landlord or those acting under the landlord’s control.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly discusses the Massachusetts covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, describes it as protecting tenants from serious interferences with their tenancy, and analyzes landlord liability based on acts or omissions, including what the landlord "permitted to be done" by others on the premises. The court holds that if the landlord fails to take measures to remove third parties whose conduct seriously interferes with tenants’ use of the premises, the landlord may be liable for breach of the covenant. This aligns with the proposition that the covenant is implied in residential tenancies and protects against serious interferences caused by the landlord or those under the landlord’s control.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 186, § 14, provides, in relevant part, that ‘any lessor or landlord who directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant’ shall be… liable to the tenant for damages…. The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold…. [A] landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, the covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in every residential lease or tenancy and protects tenants against serious interferences with their tenancy caused by the landlord or those acting under the landlord’s control.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly discusses the common-law covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law, stating that “[e]very tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy” and defining “quiet enjoyment” as freedom from serious interferences that impair the character and value of the premises. It applies this principle in the context of a residential lease and ties liability to the landlord’s conduct and that of those whose actions are attributable to the landlord, thus supporting the proposition as stated.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy. … When the Legislature chose the words ‘quiet enjoyment’ … it must have intended to incorporate these cases into the statute.”

Wesson v. Leone Enters., Inc., 437 Mass..raw_text: Wesson v. Leone Enters., Inc., 437 Mass. 708, 720 (2002)
Wesson v. Leone Enters., Inc., 437 Mass..proposition: Under Massachusetts law, the covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in every residential lease or tenancy and protects tenants against serious interferences with their tenancy caused by the landlord or those acting under the landlord’s control.
Wesson v. Leone Enters., Inc., 437 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion is a commercial lease case focused on abandoning the independent covenants rule and adopting mutually dependent covenants for commercial tenancies. It does discuss constructive eviction and the covenant of quiet enjoyment, but it does not state that a covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in every residential lease, nor does it frame its protections in the specific residential context described in the proposition. The case therefore does not provide direct authority for the asserted Massachusetts rule about residential leases.
Wesson v. Leone Enters., Inc., 437 Mass..relevant_excerpt: "Where there is a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, the tenant may raise constructive eviction as a defense to an action to recover rent. See Shindler v. Milden, 282 Mass. 32, 33-34 (1933). A constructive eviction is any ‘act of a permanent character, done by the landlord, or by his procurement, with the intention and effect of depriving the tenant of the enjoyment of the premises demised’..."

Hemingway, 363 Mass. at 199\u2013200.proposition: A landlord’s failure to correct conditions that violate the State Sanitary Code after notice can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment where such failure results in a serious interruption of the tenant’s beneficial use of the premises.

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.proposition: A landlord’s failure to correct conditions that violate the State Sanitary Code after notice can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment where such failure results in a serious interruption of the tenant’s beneficial use of the premises.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely states that a landlord’s failure to repair known defects can violate G.L. c. 186, § 14, and it specifically references failure to repair code-related defects as a common basis for § 14 liability. While the case’s immediate issue is lead paint and attorney’s fees, the court reaffirms that negligent failure to correct defects after notice, where the natural and probable consequence is interference with use of the premises, constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. That is consistent with the proposition about unremedied State Sanitary Code violations causing serious interruption of beneficial use.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.relevant_excerpt: We noted that a landlord’s failure “to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.” See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so). Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord…

Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.raw_text: Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 760–61 (1979)
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.proposition: A landlord’s failure to correct conditions that violate the State Sanitary Code after notice can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment where such failure results in a serious interruption of the tenant’s beneficial use of the premises.
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly accepts the Housing Court judge’s conclusion that the BHA’s failure to repair the leaky roof (a State Sanitary Code violation tied to habitability) interfered with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. The SJC does not disturb that liability determination; instead, it limits how damages are calculated. This affirms that a landlord’s failure to correct such defective conditions, after notice and resulting in significant interference with use, can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The BHA does not challenge the judge’s conclusion that its failures to repair the leaky roof and the defective floors were breaches of its implied warranty of habitability or his determination that the leaky roof interfered with the plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment of the leased premises…. Section 14 of G. L. c. 186 expands the measure of damages to include all ‘actual and consequential damages’ where, as here, there has been a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 199–201 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: Persistent water intrusion, dampness, and unsanitary conditions that endanger or materially impair the health or safety of occupants are substantial interferences with quiet enjoyment within the meaning of G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with loss of heat and hot water as breaches of the implied warranty of habitability and addresses rent abatement, not claims under G.L. c. 186, § 14 or the statutory concept of quiet enjoyment. It does not discuss persistent water intrusion, dampness, unsanitary conditions, or whether such conditions constitute a substantial interference with quiet enjoyment within the meaning of § 14. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition stated.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “[T]he essential objective of the leasing transaction is to provide a dwelling suitable for habitation. A dwelling afflicted with a substantial Sanitary Code violation is not habitable. The essential objective of the warranty is to make sure that the tenant receives what she is paying for. The tenant may not excuse her obligation with mere reasonable efforts to pay rent. Nor may the landlord avoid his duty with mere reasonable efforts to provide a habitable dwelling.” 379 Mass. at 201–02.

Wesson, 437 Mass. at 720.proposition: The ongoing water infiltration and associated conditions substantially impaired the value of the leasehold to Plaintiff and significantly interfered with Plaintiff’s use and enjoyment of the Premises.
Wesson, 437 Mass. at 720.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly finds that the landlord’s failure to keep the roof in repair deprived the tenant of a substantial benefit significant to the purpose of the lease and interfered with the tenant’s business operations, justifying termination and relocation damages. While the court holds the conditions did not amount to a "constructive eviction" (no legal "untenantability"), it still holds that the chronic leaks and associated risks substantially impaired the value of the leasehold under the mutually dependent covenants rule, aligning with the proposition that the water infiltration substantially impaired value and interfered with use and enjoyment.
Wesson, 437 Mass. at 720.relevant_excerpt: Based on the judge’s findings of fact, all of the requirements of the rule have been met in this case: the landlord breached his covenant to maintain the roof by failing to adequately repair its chronic leaking; the breach directly interfered with the tenant’s business by depriving it of a substantial benefit significant to the purpose of the lease; and, after adequate notice, the landlord’s efforts to correct the problem were both “shoddy and unsuccessful.” The tenant was entitled to terminate the lease and recover relocation costs in the amount determined by the judge.

Simon, 385 Mass. at 102\u201304.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landlord’s knowledge of dangerous or unhealthy conditions and failure to act can be treated as a “direct or indirect interference” with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment for purposes of G.L. c. 186, § 14.

Doe, 417 Mass. at 284\u201385.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landlord’s knowledge of dangerous or unhealthy conditions and failure to act can be treated as a “direct or indirect interference” with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment for purposes of G.L. c. 186, § 14.

Hemingway, 363 Mass. at 199.proposition: The existence of code violations and water intrusion, plus Defendant’s refusal to take adequate corrective action after inspectional enforcement, constitutes a serious interruption of the tenancy that “materially impairs the character and value of the leased premises.”
Hemingway, 363 Mass. at 199.support_reasoning: This concurring/dissenting opinion discusses implied habitability obligations tied to State Sanitary Code violations and how such violations affect the measure of rent, but it does not articulate or adopt a rule that code violations and water intrusion, combined with refusal to correct after inspectional enforcement, amount to a ‘serious interruption of the tenancy’ that materially impairs the character and value of the premises. The focus is on implying contractual obligations from statutes and limiting rent to the fair value of deficient premises, not on defining ‘serious interruption’ or using that phrase or concept as a standard. The proposition overstates and reframes what this opinion actually decides or endorses.
Hemingway, 363 Mass. at 199.relevant_excerpt: “[I]t would be sufficient for the decision of these cases to hold that the landlord, in renting the apartments to the tenants, impliedly agreed that the apartments would comply with the several requirements of the Code which the tenants allege were violated, and that if the tenants sustain their burden of proof of such violations their liability for the unpaid rent may be reduced to the fair value of their use and occupancy of the apartments in their deficient condition.”

Berman & Sons, 379 Mass. at 199\u2013201.proposition: The existence of code violations and water intrusion, plus Defendant’s refusal to take adequate corrective action after inspectional enforcement, constitutes a serious interruption of the tenancy that “materially impairs the character and value of the leased premises.”

Al-Ziab, 424 Mass. at 850\u201351.proposition: In addition, Defendant’s hostility and labeling of Plaintiff as a “problem tenant,” and Defendant’s stated intention not to renew Plaintiff’s lease shortly after Plaintiff contacted the City, underscore Defendant’s disregard of Plaintiff’s rights and contribute to the interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment.

G.L. c. 239, \u00a7 8A.proposition: G.L. c. 239, § 8A (recognizing remedies for code violations and landlord breaches in the landlord‑tenant context).
